description.en: The course examines philosophical and ethical questions related to sexuality. We will begin by analyzing the nature of sex, discussing a range of theories of sex including sex as essentially connected to reproduction, sex as a language or expression of love, "plain sex" theories that regard pleasure and desire as essential, and sexuality as a social construct. Then, we will consider more closely the ethics of sexual behaviour. Here we will examine concepts such as perversion and objectification, in particular under the lights of long-standing ethical traditions such as natural law theory, Kantianism, utilitarianism and feminism. In the final part of the course we will examine more specific ethical issues, such as the nature of sexual consent, pornography, and the rights of the disabled to sexual satisfaction. During the lectures we will go through the main concepts and arguments which will be necessary in order to comprehend and discuss the texts to be studied for the seminars.
description.et: Õppeaine vaatleb seksuaalsusega seotud filosoofilisi küsimusi. Esmalt uuritakse, mis on seks, arutledes mitmesuguste seksuaalteooriate üle. Muuhulgas käsitletakse traditsioonilist vaadet seksile kui millelegi eelkõige järglaste saamisega seotule, kujutlust seksist kui armastuse väljendamise viisist ning teooriaid, mis rõhutavad eelkõige seksuaalset naudingut. Kursuse teises pooles vaadeldakse seksuaalkäitumise eetikat, arutledes monogaamia, prostitutsiooni, seksiga nõustumise ning pedofiilia üle.

objectives.en: 1) To give an overview of the main conceptual and ethical issues related to sexuality,
objectives.et: 1) Anda ülevaade peamistest seksuaalsusega seotud mõistelistest ja eetilistest küsimustest,

objectives.en: 2) to provide an example of how philosophy can help in thinking about familiar practical issues
objectives.et: 2) näidata, kuidas filosoofia saab meid aidata igapäevaste praktiliste küsimuste mõtestamisel,

objectives.en: 3) to develop skills of critical analysis of philosophical texts,
objectives.et: 3) arendada üliõpilaste oskust filosoofilisi tekstide kriitiliselt analüüsida,

objectives.en: 4) to develop skills of rigorous argumentation on practical ethical issues, both in oral and written form,
objectives.et: 4) arendada oskust oma seisukohti praktilistes eetikaküsimustes nii suuliselt kui kirjalikult korrektselt põhjendada,

objectives.en: 5) to practice reasoned debate on highly emotional and controversial public and private questions.
objectives.et: 5)  harjutada väitlemist era- ja avalikku sfääri kuuluvate väga emotsionaalsete ja vastuoluliste küsimuste üle.

learning_outcomes.en: On successful completion of the course the student:
1) has an overview of some of the main questions and theories in ethics and philosophy of sex,
learning_outcomes.et: 1) on omandanud ülevaate seksuaaleetika ja -filosoofia peamistest küsimustest ja teooriatest,

learning_outcomes.en: 2) is able to argue in favour or against determinate claims, in oral and written form,
learning_outcomes.et: 2) oskab nii suuliselt kui kirjalikult esitada vaadeldud väidete tugevaid ja nõrku külgi,

learning_outcomes.en: 3) is able to distinguish the specific contribution of philosophy to the study of sexuality,
learning_outcomes.et: 3) teab, milline on filosoofia kui distsipliini panus seksuaalsuse uurimisse,

learning_outcomes.en: 4) is able to express their own views in a precise manner, in oral and written form,
learning_outcomes.et: 4) oskab selgelt ja täpselt suuliselt ja kirjalikult väljendada oma seisukohti vastavatel teemadel,

learning_outcomes.en: 5) is able to engage with and contribute to historical and ongoing philosophical, ethical, and social debates surrounding sexuality,
learning_outcomes.et: 5) on võimeline mõistma ajaloolisi ning tänapäevaseid filosoofilisi, eetilisi ning ühiskondlikke seksuaalsust puudutavaid debatte ning neis osalema,

learning_outcomes.en: 6) is able to engage with their peers on philosophical topics.
learning_outcomes.et: 6) oskab hõlmata kaasüliõpilasi aruteludesse filosoofilistel teemadel.

notes.et:
WARNING: The course includes material which may be found offensive, disturbing, or triggering.

In 2024/25 we will have the first meeting, all together, on 12 February, 10-12. Then we will meet in class only for SEMINARS (divided into two groups) every Wednesday times tba. LECTURES are posted as videos in Moodle.  
Leaving a substantial comment on the video BY THE SUNDAY BEFORE THE SEMINAR is required and tells me that you have "attended" the lecture. After seeing your comment, I will mark your lecture attendance on the attendance sheet. A "substantial comment" means a relevant question or a relevant remark based on the actual content of the lecture.

How to write your comment: during or after watching the video, click on the arrow that looks like this  at the bottom of the video, then write your text in the line (it can be as long as you want). Your comment will show up under your name.
Attending the lecture is crucial for understanding the texts to be discussed in seminars.

Please use Moodle e-mail for all communication with the lecturer. E-mails sent to my ut address may be discarded.

Note for those taking the course as FLFI.00.025 Autori- või probleemseminar II (3 EAP): In your case, you are not required to do the mid-term essay. You may also choose to write it, in order to get writing practice, but I won't grade it. Your overall grade will result from seminar (50%) and final essay (50%).

description.et:
Lecture attendance and active participation in seminars. This is worth 30% of the final score. 
Lectures: Lectures must be attended BY WATCHING THE RECORDED LECTURE POSTED IN MOODLE AND LEAVING A COMMENT BY THE SUNDAY BEFORE THE SEMINAR. COMMENT MEANS ATTENDANCE. Lectures are meant to provide sufficient background for a comprehension of the texts to be discussed in seminars. 
Seminars: After watching the lecture, you need to (1) read the seminar text explained in the lecture, and answer quiz questions on it (in Moodle) by 23:59 before the seminar day; (2) come to class ready to compare and discuss your quiz answers with members of a smaller group and then report to the class. 

NOTE ON PENALTIES: Missing a lecture (i.e. not watching and leaving a substantial comment by the Sunday before the seminar) means -2 points deduction from attendance. This cannot be compensated.
Every missing answer from the Moodle quiz means a -1 deduction from attendance. This cannot be compensated.
Physically missing a seminar means a -3 points deduction from attendance. You can either compensate up to two missed seminars by doing extra work assigned by the lecturer or choose to incur the -3 points penalty. If you miss 3 seminars or more, you will not pass the course, even if you compensate for them. Special exemptions must be required by the student.

Mid-term short essay. This is worth 30% of the final score (including a complimentary 10% from completing the plagiarism test). See Moodle for instructions.
Late submissions receive a -3 points penalty for each day past the deadline. If you know you will not make it by the deadline, please tell me at least 24 hours in advance, and we can set up a new deadline.

Late submissions will receive a -3 points penalty for each day past the deadline. If you know you will not make it by the deadline, please tell me at least 24 hours in advance, and we can set up a new deadline.
